publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in ŠorčuqStadthöhleduring T III Š 80.13

sourceDesc.p: Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).
Transcription and translation are based on .

seg.seg: ... (Thereupon the king) speaks, looking with [his] blue eyes onto the ministers: “Do not scold [me]!
... did he not also (?) stand by [my side]? Therefore I, too, must bear the vexation of instruction from him.”
Thereupon (the ministers) standing with threatening (?) swords at the door of the Dānaśāla with deference spoke to the
Darauf die (Minister), mit drohenden(?) Schwertern an der Tür der Dānaśālā stehend, ...
Thereupon the (ministers), standing with threatening(?) swords at Dānaśālā's door, ...
king: || In the P.-( tune): || “By the good nature [of your] kingship you have seized our heart. You are a sanctuary of virtue.
Durch die gute Art [deines] Königtums hast du unser Herz ergriffen.
Through the good nature of [your] kingship you have seized our heart.
(There is (?)) none that is to be praised more (?). And we [are], o lord, not able to bear this your anger. This rākṣasa of human birth
This rākṣasa of human birth must quickly go away from this country. (cf 36; 305)
must quickly go away from this country. I. Sadly the king speaks: “From a father all are
to be protected from danger. How [can] you command me to drive away [my] own teacher from the country?” The ministers speak: Whether the lord keeps
Die Minister sprechen: "Ob der Herr diesen Brahmanen oder uns behält, wir aber (sind) nicht imstande, mit einem derartigen Feind des Herrn (in diesem Lande zu bleiben(?))."
The ministers say: "Whether [our] lord keeps this Brahmin or us - but we (are) not able (to remain in this country(?)) with such an enemy of [our] lord."
this Brahmin or whether he keeps us, yet with such an enemy of the lord we (are) not able
(to cooperate (?)) .... Confused the king speaks: “Alas, I have truly run into danger. How...
... When (the ministers) (did not) obtain the consent of the king, below the hall, leaning upon [their] swords, (they asked him) (...) (again as follows):

p.note: A conversation between the king and his ministers. The overlaps with are particularly noticeable here. Continues (after a gap) and is in turn continued by . The translation follows 305-6, 36 and . For the Uyghur version, see 306; 10.
This fragment must be placed after and, according to 35-6, after . 305, 308 places A 342 first.
tam 'also(?)'; alternatively, 261 suggests to read täm 'there, then' instead.

śālyis 'of (the) hall', gen. sg. of śāl or alternatively, according to 261 and parallel to the case of ñäkcyis : ñäkc(i)yās, it may stand for śālyās, obl. pl. fem. of śālyi 'left'. In this latter case one would have to supplement śālyis po(ṣṣāsā).
This tune has 4x14 syllables, rhythm 7/7. also has a tune inserted at this point, but of different name and metre.

div.p: Edition188-189. Siegling's personal copy of p. 188 p. 189.

list.item: a1 ... (Thereupon the king) speaks, looking with [his] blue eyes onto the ministers: “Do not scold [me]! a2 ... did he not also (?) stand by [my side]? Therefore I, too, must bear the vexation of instruction from him.” a3 Thereupon (the ministers) standing with threatening (?) swords at the door of the Dānaśāla with deference spoke to the a4 king: || In the P.-( tune): || “By the good nature [of your] kingship you have seized our heart. You are a sanctuary of virtue. a5 (There is (?)) none that is to be praised more (?). And we [are], o lord, not able to bear this your anger. This rākṣasa of human birth b1 must quickly go away from this country. I. Sadly the king speaks: “From a father all are b2 to be protected from danger. How [can] you command me to drive away [my] own teacher from the country?” The ministers speak: Whether the lord keeps b3 this Brahmin or whether he keeps us, yet with such an enemy of the lord we (are) not able b4 (to cooperate (?)) .... Confused the king speaks: “Alas, I have truly run into danger. How... b5 ... When (the ministers) (did not) obtain the consent of the king, below the hall, leaning upon [their] swords, (they asked him) (...) (again as follows):

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a5-b1 This rākṣasa of human birth must quickly go away from this country. (cf [[Sieg, Übers. II]]: 36; [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 305) 222


Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a3 Darauf die (Minister), mit drohenden(?) Schwertern an der Tür der Dānaśālā stehend, ... 355, fn. 1
a4 Durch die gute Art [deines] Königtums hast du unser Herz ergriffen. 395
b2-4 Die Minister sprechen: "Ob der Herr diesen Brahmanen oder uns behält, wir aber (sind) nicht imstande, mit einem derartigen Feind des Herrn (in diesem Lande zu bleiben(?))." 398


Ad recto/verso order: a4 quoted as b4 in [[Carling, DThTA]]: 56 (TI)

MS "turned around" for transcription and translation, but not for translit - is it meant to be like this? (TI)

a4: [[Carling, DThTA]]: 154 has “hearts”, for “heart” on p. 56. Otherwise slightly different wording in translation, meaning the same. (TI)

a2 (new order): [[Carling, DThTA]]: 172 has a typo (?) enṣäluneṣiṃ, but enäṣluneṣiṃ on p. 92 and 95 (and above) (TI)

a3-4 (new order): the translation above follows the translation in [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 305; in [[Carling, DThTA]]: 176, the translation has “swords in the sheath” instead of “threatening (?) swords/drohenden (?) Schwertern”, and “decisiveness” instead of “Ehrenbezeugung/deference” (TI)

b2 and b3 ne better to be read as te, like in [[Barnes 2013]]: 33? – Martin (Mon, 2015-08-31, 00:22:14 (CEST))
This fragment must be placed after [[A 344]] and, according to [[Sieg, Übers. II]]: 35-6, after [[A 343]]. [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 305, 308 places A 342 first.

a1 – – – – – – – – (tmäṣ wä)l ts(eṃ yokās a)ś(ä)nyo āmāśāsac pälkoräṣ träṅkäṣ mar mäntā(cär) a2 – – – – – – – – – – mā te tam ñi ṣtmo tämyo täm ñi kälṣäl caṣäṣ enäṣluneṣiṃ erkātune || a3 tmäṣ (āmāśa)ñ kälycaṃ kāresyo tānaśolis yokmaṃc ṣtmoräṣ śla wäktasurñe lāntac|lānta|c a4 träṅk(iñc) || phull(enaṃ) || # lā(ṃ)tuneṣiṃ , kra(nt) tiryā ; āriñc wasäṃ , entsāte : #1a kāswoneyis , śmoññe naṣt ; a5 mā – – k· , yärkā y{a}l «:» #1b mā śkaṃ nātäk , was cämplye ; tñi|tñ= erkātune , caṣ klässi : #1c oñi cmolṣi , rākṣant (säm) ; b1 kalkāṣ lo ymār , caṣ ypeyäṣ : 1 || #1d klopasū nāntsu wäl träṅkäṣ pācri_(Gen.)|pācri puk w· ·ā-ñ m· – – b2 ñātseyäṣ pāṣlye mänt wätkäś|wätkäśś ñi ṣñi käṣṣiṃ ypeyäṣ tsäknātsi āmāśāñ träṅkiñc mā ne nātäk b3 caṃ brā(māṃ) e(pe) mā ne was entsaträ was nū taṃne wkäṃnyo nātkis yäsluntaśśäl mā cämplye b4 –s· – – – – – – – || mnū lutäsmāṃ wäl träṅkäṣ hai_(TA)|hai ṣokyo nu oklopac kakmu nasam kuc b5 – – – – – – – – – r tmäṣ (āmāśāñ) lāntaṣ ke kälpoṣ kāresā sāseyūṣ śālyis posaṃ|po|(saṃ)

a2. tam 'also(?)'; alternatively, [[Couvreur 1954b]]: 261 suggests to read täm 'there, then' instead.

a4. śālyis 'of (the) hall', gen. sg. of śāl or alternatively, according to [[Couvreur 1954b]]: 261 and parallel to the case of ñäkcyis : ñäkc(i)yās, it may stand for śālyās, obl. pl. fem. of śālyi 'left'. In this latter case one would have to supplement śālyis po(ṣṣāsā).

a1 – – – – – – – – – – _l\ ts· – – – – ś·nyo āmāśāsacä\ _p_alko_r_a_ṣ\ t_r_aṅ_k_a_ṣ\ ma_r\ _m_antā – – a2 – – – – – – – – – – mā te tam ñi ṣtmo _t_amyo _t_am ñi _k_a_l_ṣ_a_l\ ca_ṣ_a_ṣ\ enäṣluneṣiṃ erkātune || a3 [t]_m_a_ṣ\ – – – ñä(\) _k_alycaṃ kāresyo tānaśoli_s\ yokmaṃcä\ ṣtmo_r_a_ṣ\ śla wäktasurñe lānta a4 cä(\) t_r_aṅk(iñcä\) || phull(enaṃ) || lā(ṃ)tuneṣiṃ kra –ä\ tiryā āriñcä\ wa_s_aṃ entsāte : kāswoneyi_s\ śmoññe na_ṣ_t\ a5 [m]ā – – k· yärkā yä[_l\] mā śkaṃ nā_t_a_k\ wa_s\ [c]ämplye tñ= erkātune ca_ṣ(\) _k_l_assi : oñi cmolṣi rākṣa[n_t\] – – b1 kalkā_ṣ\ lo ymā_r\ c[a]_ṣ\ ypey[ä]_ṣ\ : 1 || klopasū nāntsu wä_l\ t_r_aṅ_k_a_ṣ\ pācri [p]u_k(\) w··ā-ñ(ä)\ m· – – b2 ñātsey[ä_ṣ\] pāṣlye _m_a[n_t\] wä_t_k_aśś [ñ]i ṣñi _k_aṣṣiṃ ypeyä_ṣ\ t_s_aknātsi āmāśāñä\ t_r_aṅkiñc\ mā [n]e nā_t_a_k\ b3 caṃ [b]rā – e – mā ne wa_s\ entsat_r_a was nū taṃne w_k_aṃnyo nātki_s\ yäsluntaśśä_l\ mā cämplye b4 –s· – – – – – – – || mnū lu_t_asmāṃ wä_l\ t_r_aṅ_k_a_ṣ\ hai ṣokyo nu oklopacä\ kakmu nasa_m\ kucä\ b5 – – – – – – – – – r _t_m_a_ṣ\ – – – – lāntaṣ ke _k_alpo_ṣ\ kāresā sāseyū_ṣ\ śālyi_s\ po

A conversation between the king and his ministers. The overlaps with [[THT 79]] are particularly noticeable here. Continues (after a gap) [[THT 77]] and is in turn continued by [[THT 80]]. The translation follows [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 305-6, [[Sieg, Übers. II]]: 36 and [[Carling, DThTA]]. For the Uyghur version, see [[Schmidt KT 2001]]: 306; [[Hamilton 1986]]: 10.

Ms should be turned around.

a4. This tune has 4x14 syllables, rhythm 7/7. [[THT 79]] also has a tune inserted at this point, but of different name and metre.

div.p: Ad recto/verso order: quoted as b4 in <citedRange>56</citedRange></bibl> (TI)</p><p>MS "turned around" for transcription and translation, but not for translit - is it meant to be like this? (TI)</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a4"/>: <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>154</citedRange></bibl> has “hearts”, for “heart” on p. 56. Otherwise slightly different wording in translation, meaning the same. (TI)</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a2"/> (new order): <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>172</citedRange></bibl> has a typo (?) <hi>enṣäluneṣiṃ</hi>, but <hi>enäṣluneṣiṃ</hi> on p. 92 and 95 (and above) (TI)</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a3-4"/> (new order): the translation above follows the translation in <bibl><title corresp="ref:schmidtkt2001"/><citedRange>305</citedRange></bibl>; in <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>176</citedRange></bibl>, the translation has “swords in the sheath” instead of “threatening (?) swords/drohenden (?) Schwertern”, and “decisiveness” instead of “Ehrenbezeugung/deference” (TI)</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__b2"/> and <ref type="ms" target="__b3"/> <hi>ne</hi> better to be read as <hi>te</hi>, like in <bibl><title corresp="ref:barnes2013"/><citedRange>33</citedRange></bibl>? – Martin (Mon, 2015-08-31, 00:22:14 (CEST))</p></project_comment>
